@aymanrady @clineamb @blacksonic @burmisov  
What exactly do you gain from [this technique](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/1044#issuecomment-72384131) over just using browserify and the `fs` module or vinyl-source-stream? E.g.:

``` js
browserify('./src/index.js')
  .transform(whatever)
  .bundle()
  .pipe(fs.createWriteStream('./build/whatever.js'));
```
- This only allows you to `gulp.src()` one entry file per bundle, right?
- You're not even using globbing.
- This only allows you to apply gulp plugins to that one file or the whole bundle output.
- Without additional effort doesn't this name the bundle after the single entry file?

@jmm I _am_ using globbing and have multiple bundles for different parts of sites I build typically.. I have different file names for each bundle...  The browserify+fs way doesn't handle globs by default like gulp does.  I use globs to select the various bundles I need.  I also typically `require()` in-file, since different files may have different dependencies, not every single bundle has the same needs. In addition, with the gulp flow, I'll get to apply various other plugins (uglify, rename, whatever) to each file individually...

My structure is usually like this when it comes to stuff I want to browserify for bigger builds that have different bundles...

```
/src
  /libs
  /models
  /etc...
  bundle1.js
  bundle2.js
  bundle3.js
    ...etc...
/public
  /js 
...etc...
```

Task ends up looking like this:

``` js
gulp.src("./src/*.js")
   .pipe(<browserify through2 style>)
   .pipe(uglify())
   .pipe(rename({extname: ".min.js"}) // if we're doing production, for example
   .pipe(gulp.dest("./public/js"))
;
```

I'll get my individual bundles this way.  I also would prefer to have my tasks all gulp-y since I use gulp for a lot of other things (less compile, hint/linting, etc.).  I have the browserify task built out in another file that I just require in my gulp file, so I can essentially do `var browserify = require('./tasks/gulp-browserify.js');` and then the pipe would be as such: `.pipe(browserify())`.  (In gulp-browserify.js would be requiring through2 and browserify doing the solution @aymanrady posted.)

@pikeas 

> Would really like to use browserify + vinyl-transform. Is this a browserify bug or a wontfix?

It's not a browserify bug. `browserify().bundle()` is documented as returning a _readable_ stream. vinyl-transform is for wrapping a _transform_ stream. While `bundle()` may technically return a writable stream, it's not intended to be written to from outside of browserify (and that's not even how the vinyl-transform technique works when it does work).

For the time being I recommend you take a look at the various techniques suggested in this thread (by others and myself) and see if one of them works for you. If not, please post more information about your situation. vinyl-transform is not a good fit for this no matter what, but if you're really intent on using it for some reason it may work by re-arranging your code as discussed in one of my earlier posts.

This issue is due to use of vinyl-transform in a way that doesn't make sense. Please note that I'm not pointing fingers at anyone for doing it, I know everyone is just trying to figure out how to integrate browserify with gulp and that's one of the techniques that's been promoted. But it was a poor choice of technique that only worked as a fluke.

For that reason I'm closing the issue. However, for the time being we can continue to use this thread to discuss ways of integrating them that _do_ make sense.

Also note that as of browserify v9.0.5 / v9.0.6 use of vinyl-transform in any variation discussed in this thread will fail 100% of the time, I believe. See #1187 and #1191.
